A researcher will conduct a study to investigate whether adding a new ingredient to a toothpaste is effective in whitening teeth. Two designs are proposed. Design <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mtext>I</mtext></math>: Randomly select <math alttext="130" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>130</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> people from a certain population to use the toothpaste with the new ingredient each day. Observe the number of people who experienced whitening of their teeth in one month. Design <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mtext>II</mtext></math>: Obtain <math alttext="130" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>130</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> volunteers. Randomly assign <math alttext="100" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>100</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> of these volunteers to a group to use the toothpaste with the new ingredient each day and <math alttext="30" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>30</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> people to a group to use a placebo (the same toothpaste but without the new ingredient) each day. Observe the number of people who experienced whitening of their teeth in each group after one month. (a) If the researcher were to choose Design <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>I</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, describe, in the context of the study, a statistical reason for using stratified random sampling instead of simple random sampling in this design.

A researcher will conduct a study to investigate whether adding a new ingredient to a toothpaste is effective in whitening teeth. Two designs are proposed. Design <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mtext>I</mtext></math>: Randomly select <math alttext="130" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>130</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> people from a certain population to use the toothpaste with the new ingredient each day. Observe the number of people who experienced whitening of their teeth in one month. Design <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mtext>II</mtext></math>: Obtain <math alttext="130" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>130</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> volunteers. Randomly assign <math alttext="100" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>100</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> of these volunteers to a group to use the toothpaste with the new ingredient each day and <math alttext="30" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>30</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> people to a group to use a placebo (the same toothpaste but without the new ingredient) each day. Observe the number of people who experienced whitening of their teeth in each group after one month. (a) If the researcher were to choose Design <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>I</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, describe, in the context of the study, a statistical reason for using stratified random sampling instead of simple random sampling in this design.

(b) The researcher is considering using an alternate design: a matched-pairs design. Explain a benefit that a matched-pairs design would bring to the investigation and identify a characteristic that can be used to group the <math alttext="130" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>130</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> people into pairs.

The researcher conducted the study using Design <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>II</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. The results of the study are shown in the following bar graph. (c) Suppose one person is randomly selected from each group (Toothpaste with New Ingredient and Placebo). A student claims that the likelihood of selecting a person who did not experience whitening is greater for the Toothpaste with New Ingredient group than for the placebo group because the total number of people who did not experience whitening is greater for the Toothpaste with New Ingredient group than for the placebo group. Explain the error in the student’s claim.

The researcher will use the sample data to complete a hypothesis test to investigate the following research question. Is there a difference between use of the toothpaste with the new ingredient and use of the placebo in the whitening of teeth? Let <math alttext="p sub T" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>T</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> be the proportion of people similar to those in the study who experience teeth whitening using the new ingredient toothpaste, and let <math alttext="p sub P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>P</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> be the proportion of people similar to those in the study who experience teeth whitening using a placebo. The hypotheses of the test used by the researcher are as follows. <math alttext="H sub 0: p sub T equals p sub P. H sub a: p sub T is not equal to p sub P." overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>{</mo><mtable columnalign="left" width="auto"><mtr><mtd><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub><mo>:</mo><msub><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>T</mtext></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>P</mtext></mrow></msub></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mtext>a</mtext></mrow></msub><mo>:</mo><msub><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>T</mtext></mrow></msub><mo>≠</mo><msub><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>P</mtext></mrow></msub></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mstyle></math> (d) Describe, in the context of the study, the consequence of making a Type <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>II</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> error.

The conditions for inference have been met. A <math alttext="98%" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>98</mn><mo>%</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> confidence interval to estimate <math alttext="p sub T minus p sub P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>T</mtext></mrow></msub><mo>−</mo><msub><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>P</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> is <math alttext="negative 0.05 comma 0.41" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>0.05</mn></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo><mn>0.41</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.(e) Based on the confidence interval, how should the researcher answer the research question? Explain your answer.
